data.title: Don Davis' talent with steel guitar opened doors to Nashville fame

data.text:
When Alabama Music Hall of Famer Don Davis was a child in

the late 1930s, a country music band played at his school in

Satsuma. One of its members leaned over a flat keyboard that

he plucked -- a steel, or Hawaiian, guitar -- and the boy was

captivated by the metallic yet melodic sound.

"It made my hair stand on end," Davis says at his

house in Gulf Shores. "I realized, 'I've got

to do that.'"

Soon young Don found a musician to give him a couple of

lessons, using a Spanish guitar turned flat. "After I

got hot on it," he says, "my parents bought me an

electric Hawaiian guitar for $39.95 from Sears-Roebuck.

We'd just gotten electricity. There was an electric

cord on the porch up to a light. I'd unplug that cord

and plug in my amplifier. The cows would come and hear the

racket. They kind of liked it." For Davis, turning 80 this month, a steel guitar opened the

door to country music glamour and fame. He played with

famous, old-time bands like Pee Wee King and the Golden

Cowboys, plucked strings as a studio musician in thousands

of recordings, and worked later as a producer.

With his flowing white hair and goatee, and rose-tinted

glasses, Davis holds forth on topics like the Grand Ol'

Opry, fellow entertainers Minnie Pearl and Hank Snow, and

the craft of steel guitar -- although he's refused to

play one for years.

He has enjoyed a colorful personal life, too, having been

married to Anita Carter, one of the singing Carter sisters

(Johnny Cash was married to sister June Carter). The couple

lived in Satsuma from 1958 to 1963, and later divorced.

Davis has been with his current wife, Serilda, 56, since the

1980s.

"We're a lowly bunch," he teases of

"steelers," the term for steel guitar players.

"I never did know a rich steel guitar picker."

When he was a boy in Calvert, Davis' family was

"poor but didn't know it."

Some of the first music he experienced came from his

grandfather who "played a five-string banjo and made

whiskey and sang dirty songs," he says.

He was inspired by the music of "the singing

cowboy," Gene Autry, and movie cowboys Lash LaRue and

Wild Bill Elliott, whose exploits he enjoyed at the Century

Theater in Mobile.

After leaving school at 14 to labor in the Mobile shipyards,

he took off to Nashville, Tenn., where his musical gifts

paid off.

The 1940s were an early heyday of country music. As Serilda

Davis remembers of going to the Grand Ol' Opry as a

child in the 1950s: "It was like heaven."

Don Davis recalls his first appearance at the Opry with Pee

Wee King. "I was shaking," he says, but that

translated into a vibrating sound on the guitar, an effect

Pee Wee King liked.

"It quivers," Serilda Davis remarks of her

husband's sound, which she has heard only on vintage

recordings.

After a stint in the Army, Davis returned to Nashville to

work and fun -- "I was just as wild as you could

get," he says impishly -- and in 1953 married Anita

Carter. Their lives together, he says, suffered under the

demands of touring. "It got to the point people would

have to introduce us," he says.

In the late 1950s, popular music began to change. On the

scene were Elvis, the Kingston Trio and Peter, Paul, and

Mary. The era of "fiddle and steel" was under the

long shadow of folk music and rock'n' roll.

"You could take the whole Grand Ol' Opry and

wouldn't enough people show up to start a fight,"

he jokes.

When Davis and Carter moved to Mobile, he hosted a TV show,

"Alabama Jubilee," that ran mornings on WKRG.

The couple had two children, both of whom live in Tennessee

today.

Davis says he and former brother-in-law Johnny Cash

"got along pretty good."

Davis brought the Shel Silverstein lyrics, "A Boy Named

Sue," to Cash, who was looking for new material at the

time.

As Cash wrote of it in his autobiography, "Man In

Black," "'Bring it on out,' I said,

thinking Don Davis must be wrong this time. It sounded like

something I knew I wouldn't want."

"A Boy Named Sue" became one of Cash's

biggest hits.

After returning to Nashville from Mobile, Davis began to

focus on the business side of music. He says that, during

recording sessions, he had come to realize "the guy on

the other side of the glass was making more than me,

producing."

Then, after decades of doing what he loved, "I hung up

my gloves. Now I'm a surfer. I sit right in that

chair" -- he says, pointing to his easy chair --

"and surf the channels."

He loves to reminisce, and is working with a Tennessee

writer on his memoirs, "From Nashville to Mobile."

But he claims to not miss playing music. "I don't

even listen to the radio."

Even as he maintains he has no samples of his guitar

playing, Serilda Davis quietly walks to the bedroom and

returns with a CD of four songs from 1946 -- recordings of

the Pee Wee King band with singer Cowboy Copas.

The songs feature Davis on the steel guitar, and Pee Wee

King on a "squeeze box," as Davis calls it.

Serilda puts the CD into a portable player and turns up the

volume. Davis' smooth, melodic, quivery, trembly steel

guitar sounds rise through the house.

Davis' hands move on the table, the fingers of his

right hand tapping. But then he makes it evident he's

just clearing papers.

"Young people aren't interested in that kind of

music anymore," he says with resignation.

But the music of the old country band keeps on.
